newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia to let banks export gold bars from Oct 1.
newsitem.headline: Russia to let banks export gold bars from Oct 1.

text.p: Russia's central bank and commercial banks licensed to deal in precious metals will be allowed to export gold and silver bars from Oct 1 under a presidential decree issued Thursday.
The decree said exports would have to be licensed by the foreign trade ministry, and such sales would be controlled by the central bank.
The export of bullion from the Russian state fund of precious metals and precious stones would require a separate decision by President Boris Yeltsin, the decree said.

The bulk of Russia's gold reserves are now held by the central bank, which has said that it plans to increase its gold reserves, which were 397 tonnes as of March-April, by 90 tonnes a year over 1997 and 1998.
The government has another 25 tonnes in separate reserves. About 122-124 tonnes of gold was mined in Russia in 1996, and 1997 output is forecast to slip to 80-110 tonnes.

Industry sources have said banks had already contracted for 14 tonnes from 1997 output and would hold 20 tonnes of gold by 1998. The central bank will buy the rest, giving it control over most of Russia's supply.
